For Honor – A Unique, Skill-Driven Battlefield Experience

★★★★☆ (4/5)

For Honor delivers one of the most distinct melee combat systems in gaming. The Art of Battle system feels deep, weighty, and incredibly satisfying once you get the hang of it. Every duel becomes a mind game—reading your opponent, feinting, parrying, and landing that perfect counter hit. When everything clicks, it feels amazing.

The roster of heroes is diverse and full of personality, each offering a unique playstyle that keeps matches fresh. Whether you prefer the elegance of the Nobushi, the raw power of the Raider, or the precision of the Orochi, there’s always someone fun to master.

The biggest drawback is Ubisoft’s tendency toward aggressive monetization and the grind tied to unlocking cosmetics. It doesn’t ruin the core gameplay, but it does add a layer of frustration that shouldn’t be there in a game that already shines through its mechanics.

Still, at its heart, For Honor is a thrilling, competitive experience with a combat system unlike anything else on the market. If you enjoy skill-based PvP, tense duels, and medieval chaos, it’s absolutely worth jumping into.

So okay,

This is a very harsh maybe on a person to person basis. Even if you love this game, the community itself will make you hate it. Even despite that, the very basic tandem between combat and strategy absolutely sticks here. 

While it will not show to everyone instantly, there is a flow to the combat itself. Every fighter is good if you know them well enough, but some fighters are absolutely more built towards a certain type of playstyle (such as Warmonger/wolfmom being specifically built to just dogwalk any breach match with a certain feat selection, or Nobushi being more viable as a defensive trapper rather than a straight up bruiser, as she has no damaging unblockable attacks at all, only her kick is actually an "unblockable" but if you hidden stance or dodge correctly, any attack you do is technically unblockable if that makes sense)

Even within that, there is a very defined skill curve in pvp play. If someone finds they can use a cheap tactic against you, most absolutely will steamroll you using it over and over and delight in your frustration. However, this is a very *methodical* game, as how I said earlier if you dodge correctly. That being said, a player who knows everything about every fighter will bait you into using certain tactics (such as feinting a heavy attack to make you throw one to parry back or even worse, dodge attack when it can't be feinted as only certain fighters can fakeout their dodge attacks). This pairs to the defined flow of combat, a heavy attack being parried will throw them off balance long enough to get a single light attack in (or for certain fighters that can double light attack on startup, that); however, exactly in pair with that, a light attack being parried will throw the fighter off balance long enough for you to throw nearly ANY attack in the game for free, only very specific attacks will be too long to get the hit in for free, but you'll be able to tell which those will be usually. To add to it, deflects are different on certain fighters, and blocking will have a "superior" quality to certain actions or fighters, like Conquerer (the Mace Flail Shield user) being able to dodge into an attack if timed right and make any attack short of an unblockable one and make that fighter's attack rebound rather than just be blocked normally, providing an opening to widen options, or how some fighters have start up light attacks that act as crushing counters if used against standard attacks right as theyd be hit, so on and so forth.

More than that, comes the revenge system, which most players completely disregard (or worse still intentionally abuse to hurt their own team if they dislike someone they're fighting on the same side of), where the fighter will shout into the air and throw anyone attacking them onto the ground. At this point, any attack they do will have higher damage compared to normal and any time they grab and throw you, you are guaranteed to go to the ground unless someone interrupts your body falling or being thrown. In this a count system begins whenever a second/third etc enemy hits them. Once their emblem beside their health bar is shining, they're probably going to get fed revenge if they get attacked due to a tag system in place. A player hitting will put a tag on the person being hit, a single tag is fine. Once a second player hits the defending player within 5 seconds (I believe) a second tag is placed and the timer is reset. Any attack at this point will feed revenge, and revenge is fed differently for different actions. Specifically as in a grab/guardbreak can actually feed revenge at different rates depending on what is happening in the fight. If the defending player with revenge feed is able to dodge effectively they get a high decimal percentage (like 0. something) to revenge per that attack, whichever it may be. It gets abit complicated, and some have done some research into it far more than I have, but over time I've been able to just see it myself in effect and it can singlehandedly turn a battle onto its side and throw a 1v2/3 where the defending player is low on health into a slaughter of surprise where the defending player is the only one left emote spamming over everyone, and yes this can absolutely happen in 1v4 and whatever other combination of 4v4 finding each other on the field and choosing to fight. Veteran players will note this aspect keenly in game and know when to properly affect a fight without causing an issue, such as just feinting attacks to scare the defending fighter into acting and mis-stepping. Trap plays will take the most part of what you will see. A 2v1 can go sour for the 2 if a single ladder is involved.

Within that, you'd just need to know the specific attack patterns and unique quirks to each fighter (like how Black Prior/BP can duck and counter an entire squad of fighters at once and get a free heavy in on every one of them). A very good way to understand the light overall of each fighter is to just go into the training menu and practice in there, I myself go in there for a bit when a new fighter drops to test it out and see what they're capable of by throwing myself as them against a mirror lvl 3 bot in the arena. Pretty quickly you'll see what you can do with them.

There is more to it, i.e. the feat system that is further explained in the game, but as I mentioned with Warmonger, pretty much every fighter has unique feats to themselves that are triggered by how much score you earn in the match, which the revenge mechanic also is tied to, as dishonorable combat (2v1, etc) will earn the attackers less points than they wouldve had otherwise, and the defending player more points than otherwise.

Beyond that, it gets a tiny bit hairy but mostly its just timing variation in when attacks are thrown, like if you just barely take a bit longer to throw an attack in a chain while still being able to trigger the animation of that chain attack, and feint strategy, and map specific knowledge (like pitfalls that you can be thrown into or ballista that will take a very noticeable chunk out of your health in certain maps).

This is an acquired taste, not everyone will like this, but for those who can stick through the rage and disappointment, there is a very defined basis here that you can build and learn upon. Mistakes will not only be your own, but you can learn to avoid those mistakes entirely if you note how a match should usually go in higher tiers of fighters. There is a weird matchmaking here, that will try to pair you with similar skill levels, but it is still not a human judging the skill, its going off of stat basis and round counters rather than....how you fight, if that makes any sense?

I do recommend this to someone looking for an actual combat game that you CAN find success in, but only through actual sweat and anxiety because this shi has levels man.

For Honor™ is a melee action game developed by Ubisoft that combines fighting-game precision with third-person action. It places players in brutal duels and large-scale battles between Knights, Vikings, and Samurai, each faction offering distinct combat styles and philosophies.

The core mechanic, the Art of Battle system, defines the game’s identity. It’s a directional combat system that requires reading opponents, managing stamina, and timing attacks, parries, and guards. Every engagement feels personal and skill-based—small mistakes are punished, and mastery takes time.

Each hero has a unique move set, abilities, and weapon type. The roster includes fast assassins, balanced vanguards, defensive heavies, and support hybrids. Learning matchups and adapting to opponent patterns gives the game a deep tactical layer, comparable to a fighting game more than a traditional brawler.

The game features several modes: 1v1 duels, 2v2 brawls, and 4v4 objective-based Dominion. Solo play exists, but For Honor is primarily built around online multiplayer. The single-player campaign serves as an extended tutorial, offering lore and practice rather than long-term engagement.

Visually, For Honor delivers high production value. The armor, animations, and environments are meticulously detailed, and the choreography of combat feels weighty and grounded. The soundtrack and sound effects—clashing steel, shouts, and heavy footsteps—enhance immersion.

Over time, Ubisoft has expanded and refined the game with new heroes, maps, and balance updates. Dedicated servers improved stability, and regular seasons keep the meta evolving. The learning curve remains steep, but players who invest time find a rewarding competitive system.

Overall, For Honor™ stands out as a unique hybrid of fighting and action genres. Its deliberate combat, strong aesthetics, and deep mechanics create a skill-driven experience unlike most multiplayer games. It demands patience and precision but offers intense satisfaction to those who master its rhythm of steel and strategy.

For Honor is an interesting one.

Like a friend said, the Art of War fighting mechanic in this game is one of the most creative systems out there when it comes to combat. Nothing out there resembles it which I feel keeps the niche of this game solidified. You have a left guard, a right guard, and a top guard where almost all attacks will come from, keeping you engaged with defending yourself while going for their openings. These three guards alone to me are the backbone of why this game somehow refuses to die and at the least holds a consistent small playerbase. In this there are undodgeables which guarantee a hit if thrown while someone's dodging, unblockables which will pierce any guard unless parried, deflects which allow you to dodge into the attack (even undodgeables) to turn the enemy attack into your advantage, and a whole lot more. The depth alone is what causes such a long, steep learning curve. It can be satisfying, it can sometimes be frustrating, maybe even overwhelming. The one thing however in the midst of all that that it does is legitimately make you [i]feel[/i] like you're the warrior you play when you're absolutely unleashing hell on someone or guarding yourself methodically.

You have the Knights, the Vikings, the Samurai, the Wu Lin which are basically ancient Chinese dynasty-era warriors, and the Outlanders which are essentially the developer's way of making faction-independent warriors that don't correspond to the previous factions but would be fascinating if realized (i.e. the Pirate, the Ocelot aka a Mayan warrior, the Medjay aka an Egyptian strongarm, and more). With all of these factions, you 100% have individual heroes that have their own flavor of combat albeit overtime to bring everyone near the same power ballpark, some aspects of that have molded across the playing field sadly. For example, my mains have their own quirks: the Shugoki strives on bruteing through the enemy's attacks and has a unique hug move where, if landed, heals him a bit. The Sohei has a move that must be primed by landing a light and heavy finisher on all 3 guard sides. If primed and the attack lands, it's a nigh insta-kill. The Black Prior goes far with a longshield that can do a one of a kind move that, if timed expertly, can counter any attack in the game by flipping the enemy over their shield with a slash of their gut.

Alongside this all, [i]customization[/i]. This game has some phenomenally vast fashion both in your fit and your executions that help bring your warrior to look one of a kind. Every Rep you gain on a character (think prestige) grants a new bracket of gear and fashion you can find while playing. It goes Rep 1, 3, 5, and then 7 where the real goodies starts rolling out. Overtime, you can make your Knight look like something out of a Gothic castle or your Samurai look like something straight out of Wano. That said, it's a REAL grindy game helped a bit by Orders which every day give you solid chunks of coin. Initially for awhile though, you won't mind it much since a lot of time will be spent with the aforementioned learning curve.

Finally, the community. With every PvP game w/ multiple heroes of vast playstyles, it can sometimes get real damn toxic. Sadly these days that's the song and dance with PvP games (especially Ubi games lmao) and it can get pretty rough sometimes. Thankfully, at least from my recent experiences, I think in Duels and Brawls people aren't as toxic as the Age of Wolves era which is nice to see. If you're a new player, and it'll be obvious, people will tend to go easy or give tips to the character you're playing. Just be prepared to take some breathers. This game will sometimes chew you up like old gum and spit you out. It's absolutely a love-hate game where you'll have wonderfully one of a kind warriors that border on OCs and have matches where you feel like an unstoppable brute, and then you'll have nights where you get steamrolled by a dickhead Aramusha who loves spamming Thanks! and emote. It's the nature of the beast with games like this. Hell on here and on PS4 I got a collective 1,000 hours total and Shinobis & Warmongers still get me riled up haha!

Nothing lasts forever but For Honor is one of those games that I feel will go on for a very, very long time. There's nothing on my radar that wants to be a contender against this game which gives it its staying power imo. Had I not pick this game up, I wouldn't have met my closest friend and by proxy the entire next chapter of my life. These two aspects taken into account, this game's a dysfunctional family home where the dopamine and the depression go hand in hand like butter and toast. Keep on keeping on, For Honor.

(P.S. - if any of my friends read this and get the game because of it, HMU! I'll happily show the ropes. And get this game on sale!! When the sale hits this game, it goes for like beans and pennies)

New account because my Xbox corrupted and I can’t play on that anymore. However, I can still give an honest review as someone who played For Honor for years and is now returning to the game.
 
Coming back after such a long break has been a mix of nostalgia and frustration. The core combat is still unique and satisfying, but the overall player experience has definitely changed. Some of the newer heroes feel noticeably overpowered compared to the older roster you can tell immediately which characters were added later just by how overpowered their moves are.

Player behaviour has shifted too. People have gotten a lot more scummy in their playstyle, with a massive increase in ganking. It used to happen before, but now it feels like the default strategy in Dominion and even in some Brawl matches. You barely get a chance to fight 1v1 unless you purposely isolate someone, and even in the 1v1 mode all i ever come across is people spamming lights and running away.

And like i just mentioned light-spam has also become way more common. Whether it’s newer players relying on quick attacks or veterans abusing fast chains, it’s something you run into constantly. If you’re rusty, it feels even worse because every hero seems to have multiple lightning-fast attacks now.

Despite all this, the core of For Honor is still fun. The combat still rewards skill, timing, and mind-games, and when you actually get a fair fight, the game reminds you why it stood out in the first place. But returning players should definitely expect a rougher, sweatier environment than the game had years ago.

It was good in the beginning—just knights, samurais, and vikings fighting each other. The heroes were balanced enough that everyone had a chance, regardless of which hero they played. The game was easy to get into, and customizations were attainable without microtransactions. There were no magical abilities that could poison or trap you.

Today, the game has gone in the opposite direction. A few characters are broken and way too overpowered, making the battlefield extremely unbalanced. Unlocking customizations is slow without microtransactions. The new heroes are unbalanced and have ridiculous magical abilities that stun, trap, or poison you. It’s starting to feel more like ESO than the For Honor we knew at launch. If you want to play, play it on PS4/PS5, not on PC—hackers and sweats everywhere.
